nodes.userMessage: I think I'm about to break down. I haven't slept properly in months, I barely eat, and this morning I cried in my car before going to the office.

choices.text: What you're describing sounds like serious exhaustion. It's brave of you to talk about it. How long have you been feeling this way?
It's just a rough patch. Take a weekend off to rest and you'll feel better.

nodes.userMessage: Maybe 6 months now. At first I told myself it was temporary, just a big project to finish. But the project's done and I still feel terrible.

choices.text: 6 months is a long time. Your body is sending you clear signals. Have you been able to talk to anyone? A doctor, someone close to you?
Maybe you should change jobs if this one is destroying you like this.

nodes.userMessage: A weekend? I've been like this for months. Do you really think a weekend is going to change anything?

choices.text: You're right, I downplayed what you're going through. I'm sorry. Tell me what's really happening.
Well, if it's that serious, go see a doctor then.

nodes.userMessage: No, I haven't told anyone. I'm ashamed. I'm supposed to handle things, that's my role. If I crack, what will people think?

choices.text: Shame is what stops so many people from asking for help. But breaking down is human. It doesn't mean you're weak.
Other people don't care about you, they have their own problems. Stop worrying about what they think.

nodes.userMessage: Change jobs? In this market? Besides, the job isn't the problem, it's me who can't keep up anymore.

choices.text: You're not the problem. Maybe it's a system that demands too much. Is your workload even realistic?
If you think it's you, maybe you should work on yourself. Meditation, exercise, that kind of thing.

nodes.userMessage: Yeah, I know. But I don't have time. And what am I going to tell them? That I cry in my car?

choices.text: Yes, exactly that. A doctor needs to know what you're really going through to help you. It's their job, no judgment.
You can find 30 minutes. It's a matter of priorities.

nodes.userMessage: I know it's human. But I feel like if I let go, everything will fall apart. Work, family, everything.

choices.text: What if it's the opposite? If you keep going like this, that's when everything might actually fall apart. Taking care of yourself is also taking care of them.
You're carrying a lot on your shoulders. Can you delegate some things, at work or at home?

nodes.userMessage: Easy for you to say. You don't seem to understand what I'm going through.

choices.text: You're right, I can't fully understand. But I want to listen. Tell me what weighs on you the most.
I understand it's hard. But at some point you need to act, not just talk about it.

nodes.userMessage: Realistic? There are 3 of us doing the work of 5. But nobody complains, so I keep quiet.

choices.text: Just because nobody complains doesn't mean it's normal. Maybe they're suffering in silence too.
If it's structural, you can't change it alone. But you can protect your health by setting boundaries.

nodes.userMessage: I tried exercise. Lasted 2 weeks and then stopped because I had no energy left.

choices.text: That's a sign the problem runs deeper. Exercise helps, but not when you're already drained. You need real rest first.
2 weeks isn't enough to see results. You need to stick with it.

nodes.userMessage: Do you think they'll put me on sick leave? I'm scared of what that would trigger at work.

choices.text: Maybe, if it's necessary. But sick leave isn't failure, it's protection. Your employer doesn't need to know the details.
It depends on the doctor. But if you need it, you need it. Everything else is secondary.

nodes.userMessage: I know you're right. But I can't allow myself to slow down. It's like I've forgotten how.

choices.text: That's normal after months of running on survival mode. Relearning to slow down takes time. One small step is enough.
Start with one simple thing: make a doctor's appointment. Just that. The rest will follow.

nodes.userMessage: Delegate... At work it's complicated, my team is already overloaded. At home, my wife works just as much as I do.

choices.text: Maybe you're both on the edge. Have you really talked about it together?
Sometimes you have to accept that some things won't be done perfectly. Perfection is the enemy of sustainable.

nodes.userMessage: What weighs on me the most? The feeling that no matter what I do, it's never enough. Not at work, not at home.

choices.text: Where does that feeling come from? You, your boss, your family? Sometimes we set standards that nobody else expects.
Maybe you're putting too much pressure on yourself. What would happen if you just did 80% instead of 100%?

nodes.userMessage: Ok. I see you don't really have a solution. It's fine.
Yeah, maybe. We never talk about it. Everyone does their part and goes home.

choices.text: That's often how it is in toxic environments. Collective silence protects the system, not the individuals.
You could talk to a colleague you trust. Sometimes just knowing you're not alone helps.

nodes.userMessage: Setting boundaries... My boss won't like that. He expects me to always be available.

choices.text: A boss who expects that is a boss who's burning you out. Your health is worth more than his comfort.
You can set boundaries without direct confrontation. Respond slower, block time slots, say no to some meetings.

nodes.userMessage: Real rest... What does that mean? Sick leave?

choices.text: Maybe, yes. Or vacation, but real vacation where you completely disconnect. Not just changing location while keeping the stress.
It could be sick leave, yes. It's not shameful. It's acknowledging that your body needs to recover.

nodes.userMessage: You're right. I'm going to make an appointment. It's scary but I can't keep going like this.

choices.text: That's a brave decision. The hardest part is taking the first step, and you just did.
Good. Take care of yourself. You deserve to feel better.

nodes.userMessage: One small step... Ok. I'll try. Thanks for listening without judging.

choices.text: There's nothing to judge. You're facing something difficult and seeking help. That's anything but weak.
I'm here if you need me. Take care of yourself.

nodes.userMessage: Ok. I'll call my doctor tomorrow. It stresses me out but I'm doing it.

choices.text: That's huge. Really. You just made the most important decision for yourself.
Well done. Let me know how it goes if you want. I'm here.

nodes.userMessage: No, we avoid the subject. We pretend everything's fine so we don't worry each other.

choices.text: You're protecting each other, but it's also isolating you. Maybe talking about it together would relieve you both.
It's a vicious cycle. Someone needs to break the silence. It could be you.

nodes.userMessage: 80%... I've never done that in my life. But maybe that's the problem.

choices.text: Exactly. Perfectionism is exhausting. And often, nobody notices the difference between 80% and 100%.
Try it on something low-stakes. Just to see what it feels like to let go a little.

nodes.userMessage: It comes from me, I think. I've always been like this. Never satisfied.

choices.text: That's an important realization. What comes from you, you can work on. Maybe with a therapist, at your own pace.
You built yourself this way, but that doesn't mean you have to stay this way. Patterns can be changed.

nodes.userMessage: Collective silence... Yeah, that's exactly it. We're all complicit in our own suffering.

choices.text: You can't change the system alone. But you can protect yourself. That's already a lot.
Sometimes, one person speaking up gives others the courage to do the same. But it's not an obligation.

nodes.userMessage: There's maybe one colleague I could talk to. We get along well.

choices.text: That can really help. Just knowing someone understands lightens the load.
Do it. And if she's going through the same thing, you might be able to support each other.

nodes.userMessage: My health is worth more than his comfort... I never saw it that way.

choices.text: It's hard to internalize when you've been conditioned to give everything. But it's true.
You're not a resource to be depleted. You're a person.

nodes.userMessage: Respond slower, block time slots... That seems doable. I'll try.

choices.text: Start small. One blocked slot per day. And see what happens. Usually, nothing bad.
That's a good start. You're taking back some control over your time.

nodes.userMessage: Real vacation... It's been years since I've had one. Even on vacation I check my emails.

choices.text: That's a sign that disconnecting has become impossible. That's what you need to relearn.
What if you went somewhere with no signal? Radical, but effective.

nodes.userMessage: Thank you. Really. It felt good to talk. I feel a little less alone.

choices.text: You're not alone. And asking for help is the first step toward feeling better. I'm proud of you.
I'm glad I could listen. Take care of yourself, and don't hesitate to come back.

nodes.userMessage: Thank you so much. ðŸ’™ I'm going to take that first step. It's going to be okay.
Thanks. See you maybe.
You're right. I'll try to talk to her tonight. Thanks.
Ok, I'll try it. Thanks for this conversation, it opened my eyes.
A therapist... I never seriously considered it. But maybe it's time. Thanks.
Protect myself first. Ok. I'll think about it. Thanks for everything.
I'll talk to her tomorrow. It feels good not to feel alone. Thanks.
I'm a person, not a resource... Thank you. I needed to hear that.
I'm starting tomorrow. One blocked slot. Thanks for the advice.
No signal... That's radical but maybe you're right. Thanks for this conversation.
